cyclone.name: HARVEY
cyclone.current_location: about 510 mi SSE of Port O’Connor, Texas
cyclone.trajectory: moving very slowly northwest and expected to accelerate slightly toward the north-northwest, taking aim at the central Texas coast and then stalling inland
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: near Port O’Connor–Matagorda Bay, central Texas coast

weather_observation.watch_coast: Storm Surge Watch from Port Mansfield to High Island; Hurricane Watch from north of Port Mansfield to San Luis Pass; Tropical Storm Watch from Boca de Catan, MX to Port Mansfield and from north of San Luis Pass to High Island
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Texas coast from Port Mansfield through High Island with effects extending into southwest Louisiana
weather_observation.wind: Tropical storm–force winds (39-57 mph) are possible at Port Arthur late Friday through Sunday with a 28 % cumulative chance and peak onset probability of 10 %. A low (4 %) chance of 50-kt gusts also exists.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Although the current Storm Surge Watch stops at High Island, minor surge of 1–3 ft is possible in Sabine Pass and adjacent waterways if the center tracks farther east than forecast.
weather_observation.rainfall: Harvey’s moisture plume could deliver 10–15 in of rain with locally higher totals, causing life-threatening flash and river flooding in the Port Arthur area.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Prolonged heavy rain could close road and rail approaches; strong rip currents and dangerous seas will hinder vessel operations and offshore transfers.
